{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3000345,"name":"vargoose84","username":"vargoose84","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/vargoose84/{size}/165453_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-30T13:28:19.002Z","cooked":"

Programming mentor here, attempting to ask a question out of my realm:

We have a talonFX driven climbing mechanism, that we are considering zeroing by driving it to a mechanical stop and detecting a current spike and then resetting it to zero.

My questions are:

  • Is it mechanically safe to the motor and climber (two steel plates squishing together) to do so?
  • Is it reliable, have you encountered issues electrically or programmatically?
  • Which measured values do I care about? (Stator current, supply current)?
  • Is there a best way to program is (examples appreciated)?
","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2022-01-30T13:55:40.614Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":81,"reads":189,"readers_count":188,"score":447.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":401773,"topic_slug":"mechanically-zeroing-a-talonfx-driven-climber","display_username":"vargoose84","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30247,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3630 Assistant Coach - Stampede Robotics"},"post_url":"/t/mechanically-zeroing-a-talonfx-driven-climber/401773/1","custom_user_title":"3630 Assistant Coach - Stampede Robotics","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3000350,"name":"Davo","username":"auscompgeek","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/auscompgeek/{size}/9867_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-30T13:58:06.770Z","cooked":"
vargoose84:

driving it to a mechanical stop and detecting a current spike

Purely from a controls POV, my first instinct would be to recommend using a limit switch instead. That way you can avoid stalling the motor for longer than necessary to zero your mechanism. I suspect the Talon FX has a way to zero on a limit switch too.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2022-01-30T13:58:06.770Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":183,"readers_count":182,"score":91.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":401773,"topic_slug":"mechanically-zeroing-a-talonfx-driven-climber","display_username":"Davo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31229,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4774 mentor, RobotPy dev, CSA/RI"},"post_url":"/t/mechanically-zeroing-a-talonfx-driven-climber/401773/2","custom_user_title":"4774 mentor, RobotPy dev, CSA/RI","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3000352,"name":"vargoose84","username":"vargoose84","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/vargoose84/{size}/165453_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-30T14:03:30.880Z","cooked":"

It may come to this, but we‚Äôve had unfortunate circumstances with limit switches breaking or repositioning.

So at minimum we‚Äôd need a fail safe such as a mechanical stop.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2022-01-30T14:03:30.880Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":169,"readers_count":168,"score":58.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":401773,"topic_slug":"mechanically-zeroing-a-talonfx-driven-climber","display_username":"vargoose84","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":31229,"username":"auscompgeek","name":"Davo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/auscompgeek/{size}/9867_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30247,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3630 Assistant Coach - Stampede Robotics"},"post_url":"/t/mechanically-zeroing-a-talonfx-driven-climber/401773/3","custom_user_title":"3630 Assistant Coach - Stampede Robotics","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3000353,"name":"vargoose84","username":"vargoose84","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/vargoose84/{size}/165453_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-30T14:07:03.157Z","cooked":"
auscompgeek:

That way you can avoid stalling the motor for longer than necessary to zero your mechanism

I think we can avoid lengthy stall times by measuring current spikes and determine what current level tells us that we‚Äôre home

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2022-01-30T14:07:03.157Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":155,"readers_count":154,"score":41.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":401773,"topic_slug":"mechanically-zeroing-a-talonfx-driven-climber","display_username":"vargoose84","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30247,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3630 Assistant Coach - Stampede Robotics"},"post_url":"/t/mechanically-zeroing-a-talonfx-driven-climber/401773/4","custom_user_title":"3630 Assistant Coach - Stampede Robotics","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3000360,"name":"Dan Katzuv","username":"dan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/eada6e/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-30T14:42:18.588Z","cooked":"
vargoose84:

switches breaking or repositioning.

Magnetic limit switches are a great alternative.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2022-01-30T14:42:18.588Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":147,"readers_count":146,"score":64.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":401773,"topic_slug":"mechanically-zeroing-a-talonfx-driven-climber","display_username":"Dan Katzuv","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32004,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5987 Software Mentor üáÆüá±"},"post_url":"/t/mechanically-zeroing-a-talonfx-driven-climber/401773/5","custom_user_title":"5987 Software Mentor üáÆüá±","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3000370,"name":"Cameron Earle","username":"came20","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/came20/{size}/201656_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-30T15:19:07.095Z","cooked":"

I‚Äôve done this pretty successfully in the past with no issues to report. I would recommend using velocity as a measure of if you‚Äôve stopped rather than current, as the resolution and update rate of the current measurements isn‚Äôt great (it‚Äôs much easier to just detect ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been at (near) zero speed for .25 seconds, I‚Äôm homed‚Äù).

I‚Äôd recommend using a low-ish voltage during this homing so you aren‚Äôt pushing anything too hard.

Interesting solution!

Instead of a limit switch, you can look into a Hall Effect sensor or an optical solution like the Talon Tach, provides the same function as zeroing while remaining contactless

I‚Äôm a fan of these:
https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/littelfuse-inc/59065-010/43966

Works with either polarity magnet. easy to mount and adjust. Cheap (use your Digikey PDV)

WCP Sensors","clicks":10},{"url":"https://www.adafruit.com/product/158?gclid=Cj0KCQiAi9mPBhCJARIsAHchl1yhMK2ObaUIDlVP5RW3Poc9MDOSDwIRSF8yPwA-Busj3CIlbswbAqwaArooEALw_wcB","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Hall effect sensor [US5881LUA] : ID 158 : $2.00 : Adafruit Industries, Unique & fun DIY electronics and kits","clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":30247,"username":"vargoose84","name":"vargoose84","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/vargoose84/{size}/165453_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49878,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/mechanically-zeroing-a-talonfx-driven-climber/401773/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3000515,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-31T00:50:37.726Z","cooked":"

As @came20 stated, you most likely don‚Äôt need to apply full power when zeroing your mechanism. You can start with some very low power level that cannot do any damage to see if can overcome the friction and makes the mechanism move. You can then gradually bump up the power level until it does move. Depending on the range of motion, it may be difficult to measure the position frequently enough to calculate the velocity when the mechanism is unloaded and you are using a high power level.

If you can monitor the motor current and can keep it in the safe range for your motor when using a low power level, it may be possible to estimate or measure how long the motor needs to be on to get the mechanism to hit the mechanical end stop then use a slightly longer on-time. This technique is used frequently by the more accomplished FLL teams but I have never heard of the motors they have available to them being damaged by being stalled.
